facts.text: Appeal is Civil Appeal No.241 of 1961

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No.241 of 1961. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 4, 1958, of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 1335 of 1952.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated March 4, 1958 of Patna High Court in Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 1335 of 1952

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 4, 1958, of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 1335 of 1952. S. Sinha and R.C. Prasad, for the appellants.

facts.text: Plaintiff owned 1.67 acres of lands recorded in Khata 56 and 10.56 acres in Khata 57 in village Sarifabad

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff who owned 1.67 acres. of lands which were recorded in Khata 56 and 10.56 acres in Khata 57 in village Sarifabad gave 1.27 acres out of Khata 56 and 8.24 acres out of Khata 57 lands in mortgage to the several defendants by separate mortgage bonds.

facts.text: Plaintiff gave 1.27 acres out of Khata 56 and 8.24 acres out of Khata 57 in usufructuary mortgage to several defendants by separate mortgage bonds

anchor.surface_text: gave 1.27 acres out of Khata 56 and 8.24 acres out of Khata 57 lands in mortgage to the several defendants by separate mortgage bonds. Part of the remaining land was sold by him and the rest settled by him with the first defendant on Batai terms.

facts.text: Under mortgage bonds, mortgagees were liable to pay rent to the landlord

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs case is that under the terms of the mortgage bonds the mortgagees were liable to pay rent to the landlord. The mortgagees however defaulted in the payment of rent for some years.

facts.text: Mortgagees defaulted in payment of rent for some years

anchor.surface_text: The mortgagees however defaulted in the payment of rent for some years. A suit for the arrears of rent was brought by the landlord and a decree obtained.

facts.text: Landlord brought suit for arrears of rent and obtained decree

anchor.surface_text: A suit for the arrears of rent was brought by the landlord and a decree obtained. In execution of the decree the lands were sold.

facts.text: In execution of rent decree, the lands were sold; purchasers were Besolal and Mst. Kirti Kuer

anchor.surface_text: In execution of the decree the lands were sold. The purchasers were one Besolal and Mst. Kirti Kuer, who according to the plaintiff, were only benamidars of defendants 1 and 2 and other mortgagees.

facts.text: Plaintiff claimed Besolal and Mst. Kirti Kuer were benamidars of defendants 1 and 2 and other mortgagees

anchor.surface_text: who according to the plaintiff, were only benamidars of defendants 1 and 2 and other mortgagees. It is his case that this purchase enured for the benefit of the mortgagor, that is, the plaintiff, and so the right of redemption of the mortgagees has number been affected.

facts.text: Plaintiff claimed purchase enured for benefit of mortgagor (plaintiff), right of redemption not affected

anchor.surface_text: It is his case that this purchase enured for the benefit of the mortgagor, that is, the plaintiff, and so the right of redemption of the mortgagees has number been affected. The prayers were for a declarations that the purchase was for the benefit of the plaintiff and for redemption of the mortgagees.

facts.text: Suit contested by defendants 1 and 2 only; Chamroo Sao (def1) is purchaser, Besolal (def2) son of Mst. Kirti Kuer

anchor.surface_text: The suit was companytested by defendants 1 and 2 only. Of these defendants, Chamroo Sao is the purchaser, and Besolal, defendant 2 is the son of the other purchaser Mst. Kirti Kuer.

facts.text: Defendants denied benami and claimed right of redemption extinguished by court sale

anchor.surface_text: They denied the allegation that Besolal and Mst. Kirti Kuer were their benamidars and companytended that the right of redemption has been extinguished by the companyrt sale.

facts.text: Trial Court held plaintiff failed to show auction purchasers were benamidars of mortgagees, dismissed suit

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court held that the plaintiff had failed to show that the auction purchasers were benamidars of the mortga- gees and in that view dismissed the suit.

facts.text: Additional District Judge, Patna on appeal held purchase really by first and second defendants, mortgagees liable for rent, default by both, equity of redemption subsists, passed preliminary decree for redemption

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the Additional District Judge, Patna, came to a companytrary companyclusion. He held that the put-chase, though in the name of Besolal and Mst. Kirti Kuer was really by the, first and the second defendants. He also accepted the plaintiffs case that under the terms of the mortgage bonds the mortgagees were liable to pay the rent and the rent sale having been brought about due to the default of the mortgagor and the mortgagee they companyld number be allowed to take advantage of the sale.

facts.text: Patna High Court Division Bench held s.90 Trusts Act did not apply, allowed appeal, restored Trial Court decree

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench of the High Court held that s. 90 of the Trusts Act did number apply to these circumstances. In this view the High Court allowed the appeal, set aside the decree of the first appellate companyrt and restored the decree of the Trial Court.

facts.text: Single Judge found rent liability: 2.67 acres on def1, 8.7 acres purchased +1.76 ijra (total 2.43? acres?) on def2, 3.83 on other defs, plaintiff liable for 3.39 acres out of total 1.67 Khata56 +10.65 Khata57

anchor.surface_text: On a companysideration of the evidence, he was of opinion that the liability of rent of 2.67 acres was upon defendant I and that payment of rent of 87 acres which was purchased and 1.76 acres which was taken in ijra, the total being 2.43 acres, was upon defendant 2, that for payment of rent of 3.83 acres was upon the other defendants, and the plaintiff was liable to pay the rent of only about 3.39 acres out of the entire area of 1.67 acres of Khata number 56 and 10.65 acres of Khata number 57.

facts.text: Supreme Court is allowing appeal by Mst. Basmati Devi, legal representative of original plaintiff

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal by Mst. Basmati Devi, who is the legal representative of the original plaintiff who was substituted in his place, is against the High Courts decision dismissing the suit.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds s.90 Trusts Act applies even if default by both mortgagor and mortgagee; mortgagee gained advantage by position

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the fact that the mortgagor had made a default, does number alter the position that the mortgagee had also defaulted in paying the rent he was liable to pay. By his default he has companytributed to the position that a suit had to be brought for arrears of rent and ultimately to the position that the property was put to sale in execution of the decree obtained in the suit.

facts.text: Khata 56 and 57 holdings were consolidated into one holding with one rental

anchor.surface_text: As the oral and documentary evidence on the Paper Book prepared in the appeal did number clearly show whether or number these two holdings had become one, we called for one of the documents, Ex. B which seemed likely to throw some light on the matter. ... It was decided hat such companysolidation had taken place.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside High Court judgment, restores Additional District Judge decree, orders Pleader Commissioner, court fees on defendants

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we allow the appeal, set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court and restore the decree made by the Additional District Judge, Patna. A Pleader Commissioner shall be appointed by the trial companyrt on a deposit of Rs. 50/- as his fees by the present appellant within two months from this date for taking accounts as to the amount due to the defendants on the date of the decree.

facts.text: Suit and appeal before District Judge brought in forma pauperis; High Court ordered plaintiff to pay court-fee; Supreme Court sets aside, orders defendants 1 and 2 to pay

anchor.surface_text: As the suit as also the appeal before the District Judge had been brought in forma pauperis the High Court made an order- directing the plaintiff to pay the companyrt-fee on the plaint as well as on the memorandum of appeal. That order is set aside. Instead, we order the first and the second defendants in the suit to pay the companyrt-fee payable on the plaint as also on the memorandum of appeal.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 3, 1964 by DAS GUPTA, J.

anchor.surface_text: April 3, 1964. The judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-This appeal arises out of a suit for re- demption of a large number of usufructuary mortgages in favour of the defendants.

facts.text: Defendants 1 and 2 liability substantial portion of rent

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the finding is that the liability of the defendants 1 and 2 was to pay a substantial portion of the rent.

anchor.surface_text: In companying to a companyclusion that s. 90 of the Trusts Act did number apply to cases where the sale took place due to the default of the mortgagor as well as the mortgagee,

Section 90 of the Indian Trusts Act is in these words - Where a tenant for life, companyowner, mortgagee or other qualified owner of any property, by availing himself of his position as such, gains an advantage in derogation of the rights of the other persons interested in the property, or where any such owner, as representing all persons interested in such property, gains any advantage, he must hold, for the benefit. of all persons so interested, the advantage so gained but subject to repayment by such persons of their due share of the expenses properly incurred, and to, an indemnity by the same persons against liabilities properly companytracted, in gaining such advantage. The question for companysideration is whether in circumstances like the present where the decree and the sale in execution of it are brought about by the default of both the mortgagor and the mortgagee, the mortgagee can be said to have taken advantage of his position by purchasing the property at the sale.

concepts.interpretation: Court holds it applies even if both defaulted; mortgagee's default contributed to sale, so purchase is advantage from position as mortgagee, enures to mortgagor's benefit

holdings.text: Section 90 of the Indian Trusts Act applies even where the rent sale is due to default of both mortgagor and mortgagee; the mortgagee's purchase at the sale constitutes gaining an advantage by availing his position as mortgagee, which enures to the benefit of the mortgagor.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the fact that the mortgagor had made a default, does number alter the position that the mortgagee had also defaulted in paying the rent he was liable to pay. By his default he has companytributed to the position that a suit had to be brought for arrears of rent and

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mortgagee's default causally contributed to rent arrears suit and sale; purchase at execution sale directly avails position as mortgagee in possession; High Court view unrealistic and puts premium on dishonesty; textual reading of s.90 not limited to sole default.

holdings.text: The position holds even if mortgagee's rent liability is less than major portion but substantial, as here for defendants 1 and 2.

anchor.surface_text: This, in our opinion, is the position in law even if the mortgagees liability was to pay less than the major portion of the rent of the holdings. Whether this would be true even where the portion which the mortgagee is liable to pay is so very small

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies s.90 to facts where liability substantial; reserves on minimal liability.

holdings.text: Khata Nos. 56 and 57 were consolidated into one holding with joint rental liability; mortgage bond Ex.2 accepting mortgagor's liability for Khata 57 rent does not negate mortgagees' partial liability post-consolidation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence from Ex.B judgment confirms consolidation; contradicts respondents' own plea; sale was of consolidated holding.

holdings.text: Equity of redemption subsists; plaintiff entitled to preliminary decree for redemption on payment of amounts due.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of s.90 to facts; restores lower appellate decree allowing redemption.

anchor.surface_text: Whether this would be true even where the portion which the mortgagee is liable to pay is so very small that the property is number ordinarily likely to be brought to sale for that amount, it is unnecessary

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicitly reserved as unnecessary to present facts.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we allow the appeal, set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court and restore the decree made by the Additional District Judge, Patna.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we allow the appeal, set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court and restore the decree made by the Additional District Judge, Patna.

This, in our opinion, is the position in law even if the mortgagees liability was to pay less than the major portion of the rent of the holdings. Whether this would be true even where the portion which the mortgagee is liable to pay is so very small
Accordingly, we allow the appeal, set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court and restore the decree made by the Additional District Judge, Patna.
